The good news is you made it through a summer of constant rain, mosquito paranoia and camps that charge for two months about what it costs to send a kid to Harvard for a year. PSHEW.

The good news is you made it through a summer of constant rain, mosquito paranoia and camps that charge for two months about what it costs to send a kid to Harvard for a year. The bad news is you have to come back to the real world, which is far worse. Assuming you survived the first week of school, here's a back-to-school pop quiz to help you realign your brain with those of your children. Calculators and laptops allowed.
1. What is the correct weight of a backback for a 90-pound sixth grader?
A. 20 pounds.
B. 35 pounds.
C. The approxmiate weight of Volumes A through P of the World Book.
D. The approximate weight of the defensive line of the New York Jets.
2. When should you start worrying about where your child will go to college?
A. When you get your baby's APGAR score.
B. When you figure out by second grade that your child will not get a basketball scholarsip to UConn or a football scholarship to Florida State.
C. When the probation officer tells you there are no problem kids, just kids with problems.
D. When the other children's early admission decisions start coming back.
3. How many pockets are there in the typical pair of cargo pants worn by the typical New Jersey middle school student?
C. 7 cubed.
D. One of those infinite numbers like the number of planets in the galaxy.
4. Britney Spears, Mandy Moore, Christina Aguilera and all those other blond nymphets on MTV are:
A. Appropriate role models for 9-year-old girls.
B. Appropriate role models for 45-year-old women.
C. Appropriate romantic fantasy figures for 13-year-old boys.
D. Appropriate romantic fantasy figures for 50-year-old men.
E. All of the above.
F. Houston, we have a problem.
5. Your children may be overscheduled if:
A. Your daughter goes to ballet class in her tai chi uniform.
B. You have school-optional weeks so your children can catch up on their lessons, classes and practices.
C. For the rest of the year, you will only see them on Thanksgiving, Christmas and New Year's.
D. Your piano teacher is driving a Lexus and you're working three jobs.
6. Which of the following is not biologically essential to survival for the average high school student.
A Water.
B. Cell Phone.
C. Discman.
D. Diet Coke.
E, Their own car.
7. Which form of body piercing would force you to disown your child forever and deny any knowledge of his or her existence?
A. Navel.
B. Eye.
C. Nose.
D. Chin.
E. Tongue.
F. The ones we can't mention in this newspaper.
8. Nutritionists say a healthy breakfast for a high school student should consist of:
A. Cereal, fruit, juice, milk, vitamins.
B. Egg McMuffin, Coke and hash browns.
C. Chocolate doughnut and Jolt Cola.
D. Frappucino and Cheez Doodles.
9. True or false?
A. Regis Philbin.
B. ''And he wrote every word of the college application essay himself!''
C. ''College admissions consultants? No, we didn't use any.''
D. ''Steroids? No, no one on the wrestling team is using any steroids.''
10. According to the best education research, the optimal way for teenagers to do their homework is:
A. Wearing headphones, listening to Mozart sonatas.
B. Wearing headphones, listening to Nine Inch Nails.
C. Wearing headphones, listening to Nine Inch Nails and watching ''Dawson's Creek.''
D, Wearing headphone, listening to Nine Inch Nails, watching 'Dawson's Creek'' and talking to friends on the phone.
E. Your child doesn't do homework.
11. What's the correct term for the boy with the thick glasses, pocket protector and 800's on his math SAT's who stays up all night playing esoteric computer games?
A. Nerd.
B. Wonk.
C. Dweeb.
D. Doof.
E. Boss.
SOAPBOX Peter Applebome is a deputy metropolitan editor of The Times.
